title: Was BBC One drama Dublin Murders actually filmed in Dublin?
text:
Dublin Murders centres on a mystery killer in Ireland (Picture: BBC)

BBC One has a stylish new Monday night thriller hitting our screens tonight, in the shape of Dublin Murders.

The thriller, based on the novels In The Woods and The Likeness by author Tana French, sees actors Sarah Greene and Killian Scott as detectives investigating the murder of a young ballerina, and a second murder that becomes linked to the crime.

As the title might suggest the show is of course set in Dublin – taking place in the early part of the millennium – but was it actually filmed there too?

Here’s what you need to know about the new show’s locations…

Where was Dublin Murders filmed?

While much of the show was indeed filmed at locations in Dublin, much of it was also shot in Belfast and the surrounding areas

The woods where the murder takes place are actually located were in fact shot in Tollymore Forest in Northern Ireland, a location which has also been used for the likes of Game Of Thrones and the movie Dracula Untold.

Much of the series was shot in Northern Ireland including the forest where the murder victim is found (Picture: BBC)

The village of Drumaness, in Northern Ireland, was also used for scenes set in the 1980s – with local press reporting last year that 80s-era Garda cars, green post boxes and ‘vintage Mr Whippy ice-cream vans had been spotted in the area’ as filming took place.

The show also uses some familiar buildings in and around Belfast (Picture: BBC)

In fact it’s not just the locations given an 80s look for the flashback scenes, as director Saul Dibb explained: ‘It’s set in 2006, we looked at Fujifilm stock for the 2006 period and we looked, then again for the 1980s for more of a 16mm Kodak film.

There would be subtle differences between the look of the two periods, but without ever trying to do something that felt too forced or contrived.’

Some sets were given an 80s-era theme as the action hops backwards and forwards in time (Picture: BBC)

Other locations include Crumlin Road Gaol – the only remaining Victorian-era prison in Northern Ireland, now a tourist attraction and with a rich history of its own, having been built over 150 years ago and said to harbour the ghosts of prisoners executed within its walls.

Irish viewers may well spot a few familiar places (Picture: BBC)

You’ll also get to see Ards Community Hospital in Newtonards as well as scenes shot in Custom House Square in Belfast.

‘

When is Dublin Murders on?

The series begins on BBC One on Monday night at 9pm.
